722044f.title: Manhattan: Park Avenue - 34th Street (East)
722044f.text:
Park Ave., east side, at East 34th Street. This view shows the Lex-
ington Ave. Subway under construction, which will run under the former rail-
road tunnel which is used by street cars at this time. The 71st Regiment
Armory appears on the right.
October 4,.1900.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
William B. Farsons Collection.

712141f-b.title: Manhattan: 34th Street - Park Avenue
712141f-b.text:
A portion of the same, at a later date, and showing a more restricted
view of the block from Park Ave., to but not including Lexington Ave.
The 20-story apartment house seen prominently, is the Green-Park Building,
bearing Nos. 107-113 East 34th Street, on the site where formerly stood
four 5-story houses, Nos. 107 to 113, seen in view 1. Shown also, is a
2(8neral view northward of the surrounding area, from the 71st Regiment
Armory, at the S.E. corner of Park Ave. and 34th Street, with the
Chrysler, Chanin, and New York Central Buildings appearing in the background
(from right to left).
February 27, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

722041f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Avenue - 34th Street
722041f-a.text:
Park Avenue, norph from 34th Street, showing buildings along the
east side.
The old Robb mansion on the N. E. corner of 35th Street houses the
Advertising Clu., ho occupied it early in 1923. Behind it may
be seen the skeleton of the Town House apartnents at 10B East
38ph Street, under construction. In the right background rise the
comoleted Chanin Builcing and the nearly completed Chrysler Buiiain8.
or diagonally Op,osite corners of Lexington Avenue anc 42nc Street.
In the left background the New York Central Building, 230 Park
Avenue at 4oth Street, towers over the Trand Central Station.
Early 1930.
Ewing Gallowav, Photographer.

722080f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Avenue - 34th Street
722080f-a.text:
Park Avenue, south on west side, fromm 39th to 34th Streets, seen
from 40th Street.
The old residence on the S.W. corner of 39th Street will be de-
molished in September 1933. The 70 Park Avenue Hotel, shown
on the N.W. corner of 38th Street, was built since 1925; and
on the S.W. corner of 37th Street the houses are still standing
that will give way in 1930 to the new Union League Clubhouse.
The Vanderbilt Hotel, on the block from 34th to 33rd Streets,
is shown at the extreme left.
May 6, 1928.
P. L. Sperr, Photogapher.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

722038f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Avenue - 34th Street
722038f-a.text:
Park Avenue north from 34th Street, showing the contrast of the
old and new in the transition era.
On the northwest corner of 34th Street stands the Community Church
or Church of the Messiah (Unitarian), build in 1867. It will be
demolished in 1931. Above it stands a new apartment house.
On the east side in the same block, the 15 Park Avenue apartment
house was built about 1923; and the small house on the S. E. corner
of 35th Street is about to be demolished to make room for a simi-
lar 16-story apuartment hotel. On the N. E. corner of 35th Street
the old Robb house has been occupied since 1923 by the Advertising
Club, after having been a ooarding house for some years. The
Women's City Ciub occupies the house on t he N. W. corner opposite.
The next new apartment building on the east side is The Russell,
the 9-story house erected in 1923 on the S. E. corner of 37th
Street, the site of the old Judge Russell residence.
April 19cc5.
Brown Brothers, Photographers.
.AY BE Rrhu.UCD.

Neg  ~1514
(2) V

722031f.title: Manhattan: Park Avenue - 34th Street
722031f.text:
5 Park Avenue, formerly 1 Park Avenue, residence of
Mrs. Robert Bacon, at the N.E. corner of 34th Street.
When the new One Park Avenue office building between
32nd and 33rd Streets was opened in 1926, Mrs. Hacon sought
in the courts to preserve that number for her house; and it
was restored to her by the Appelate Court in November 1927,
but finally lost to her in February 1928.
The old buildings surrounding this house have been
demolished, and an L-shaped apartment house, the Green Park,
will be built around it.
1930
Ewing Balloway, Photographer
NO REPRODUCTIONS

722034f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Avenue - 34th Street (East)
722034f-a.text:
Park Ave., at the S.E. corner of East 34th Street, showing the
tower atop the 71st Regiment Armory at that location and viewed north-
westward from No. 1 Park Ave. In the background, beyond same is the
tall No. 10 East 40th Street Building, so nearly in line with No. 500
Pifth Ave. as to almost hide the latter. Note in the lower foreground
the roofs of the Community Church and the Green residence (old No. 1
Park Ave.) on the left and right of the Armory tower respectively.
The former has been replaced by a modern apartment house. This set
consists of a negative and positive photostat of an original photograph
which was discoloring in the files.
January 15, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

722047f-a.text:
Park Avenue, west side, from East 34th to 35th Street's,
showing prominently the Community Church at the N. E. corner
of the first point. At the iight is the Church of the Cove-
nant at a similar location at 35th Street. In the foreground
1s the former railroad tunnel that extends to 42nd Street.
At the date of this nhoto it is being used for street-cars.
On the left margin is a private dwelling occupying a portion
of the site of the future Hotel Vanderbilt.
Prior to 1890

722036f-b.title: Manhattan: Park Avenue - 34th Street (East)
722036f-b.text:
Park Avenue, west side, south from East 34th Street, showing
the Hotel Vanderbilt (erected 1911) and the office structure, No. 2
Park Avenue. Each of these occupy an entire block frontage, the
the former, 34th to 33rd and the latter, 33rd to 32nd Streets.
Fourth Avenue begins at the last mentioned street. Note the vague
outline of the New York Life Iygsurance Company Building at the
upper left and the partially dismantled Community Church in the
lower right. The latter was replaced by the apartment-hotel No. 10
Park Avenue.
View 2 1s limited to the Vanderbilt Hotel elevation.
February 27, 1931
Views 1,2
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS
